FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">54.2</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">%</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px" valign="bottom" align="right" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: right" valign="bottom" width="9%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">54.5</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">%</font></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Approximately 54% of the Company&#8217;s Primary risk in force was concentrated in ten&#160;states at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.&#160;&#160;The distressed markets, which collectively represent approximately 22% and 24%, respectively, of our direct Primary risk in force as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, have been impacted disproportionately by home price depreciation as compared to the rest of the United States.</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Insurance regulations generally limit the writing of mortgage guaranty insurance to an aggregate amount of insured risk no greater than twenty-five times the total of statutory capital, which is defined as the statutory surplus plus the statutory contingency reserve. The Corrective Orders under which Triad is currently operating specifically prohibit the writing of new insurance by Triad.&#160;&#160;The risk-to-capital ratio of Triad is greater than the 25:1 regulatory guideline.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 25.2pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Triad has entered into two Corrective Orders with the Department. Among other things, the Corrective Orders:</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require the oversight of the Department on substantially all operating matters;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Prohibit all stockholder dividends from Triad to TGI without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Prohibit interest and principal payments on Triad&#8217;s surplus note to TGI without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Restrict Triad from making any payments or entering into any transaction that involves the transfer of assets to, or liabilities from, any affiliated parties without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require Triad to obtain prior written approval from the Department before entering into certain transactions with unaffiliated parties;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require that all valid claims under Triad&#8217;s mortgage guaranty insurance policies are settled 60% in cash and 40% by recording a DPO;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require the accrual of simple interest on the DPO at the same average net rate earned by Triad&#8217;s investment portfolio; and</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require that loss reserves in financial statements prepared in accordance with SAP as set forth in the Illinois Insurance Code or prescribed by the Department be established to reflect the cash portion of the estimated claim settlement but not the DPO.</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The DPO is an interest bearing subordinated obligation of Triad with no stated repayment terms.&#160;&#160;The requirement to settle claims with both the payment of cash and issuance of a DPO became effective on June 1, 2009.&#160;&#160;At December 31, 2011, the recorded DPOs, which included accrued interest of $30.6 million, amounted to $629.7 million or 81% of total invested assets.&#160;&#160;&#160;The recording of a DPO does not impact reported settled losses as these are reported as the entire amount of a claim in the Company&#8217;s results of operations.&#160;&#160;The accounting treatment for the recording of the DPO on a SAP basis is similar to a surplus note that is reported as a component of statutory surplus; accordingly, any repayment of the DPO or the associated accrued interest is dependent on the financial condition and future prospects of Triad and is subject to the approval of the Department.&#160;&#160;However, in these financial statements prepared in accordance with GAAP, the DPO and related accrued interest are reported as a liability.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Triad reported a net loss calculated under SAP of $187.8 million for 2011 compared to $143.6 million for 2010 and had policyholders&#8217; surplus of $234.7 million and $225.9 million, respectively, at December 31, 2011 and 2010.&#160;&#160;At December 31, 2011, the cumulative effect of the DPO requirement on statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus, including the impact of establishing loss reserves, was to increase statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus by $967.5 million over the amount that would have been reported absent the second Corrective Order.&#160;&#160;The cumulative increase to statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus attributable to the DPO requirement was $818.8 million at December 31, 2010.&#160;&#160;There is no such impact to loss reserves or stockholders&#8217; deficit calculated on a GAAP basis.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The second Corrective Order provides financial thresholds, specifically regarding the statutory risk-to-capital ratio and the level of statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus that, if met, may indicate that the Department should reduce the DPO percentage and/or require distributions to DPO holders.&#160;&#160;The Corrective Orders required that the Department consider whether such changes should be made or payments allowed from time to time.&#160;&#160;In January 2012, Triad was notified by the Department that based upon Triad&#8217;s surplus position, risk-to-capital ratio and the continued economic uncertainty, the Department had determined that it was inappropriate to reduce the DPO percentage or require Triad to make a distribution to the DPO holders at this time.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Reported statutory policyholders surplus for Triad, which has remained relatively consistent since the application of the DPO as part of the Second Corrective Order, was $234.7 million at December 31, 2011 compared to $225.9 million at December 31, 2010.&#160;&#160;This level of statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus has lessened the likelihood that Triad will be placed into conservatorship or liquidated.&#160;&#160;However, there remains substantial doubt about the Company's ultimate ability to pay all or a portion of the DPO and related interest and continue as a going concern.&#160;&#160;The Company's consolidated financial statements do not include any adjustments that reflect the financial risks of Triad entering receivership proceedings and assume that it will continue as a going concern.</font></div></div>
      <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">6.&#160;&#160;Federal Income Taxes</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Income tax benefit differed from the amounts computed by applying the Federal statutory income tax rate to income before taxes as follows:</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%"><tr><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 2px" valign="bottom"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr><tr><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 2px solid" valign="bottom"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr><tr bgcolor="#cceeff"><td valign="bottom"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr><tr bgcolor="white"><td valign="bottom" align="left" width="76%"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;Income tax expense (benefit) computed at statutory rate</font></div></td><td valign="bottom" align="right" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;Net deferred tax liability</font></div></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px" valign="bottom" align="right" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">$</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: right" valign="bottom" width="9%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">-</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px" valign="bottom" align="right" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">$</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: right" valign="bottom" width="9%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">-</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company cannot determine that any of its deferred tax assets will result in future tax benefits with any degree of certainty; therefore, a valuation allowance was established for the portion of these assets that are not currently expected to be realized.&#160; At December 31, 2011, the Company established a valuation allowance of approximately $346.0 million against a $355.6 million deferred tax asset.&#160; Based upon a review of the Company's anticipated future taxable income, and also including all other available evidence, both positive and negative, the Company concluded that it is more likely than not that the $355.6 million of the gross deferred tax assets, net of $9.7 million of deferred tax liabilities, will not be realized.&#160;</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2011, the Company had a NOL carryforward on a regular tax basis of approximately $627.0 million.&#160;&#160;Of this amount,&#160;if it remains unused, $195.3 million expires in 2028, $85.6 million expires in 2029, $126.6 million in 2030, and $219.5 million expires in 2031. The amount and timing of realizing the benefit of NOL carryforwards depends on future taxable income and limitations imposed by tax laws. &#160;The benefit of the NOL carryforward has not been recognized in the consolidated financial statements.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In May 2011, shareholders approved a Tax Benefits Preservation Plan (&#8220;Plan&#8221;) (previously approved by the Board of Directors in September 2010) and amended the TGI certificate of incorporation to help protect its ability to recognize certain potential tax benefits in future periods from net operating loss carryforwards and tax credits, as well as any net operating losses that may be generated in future periods (the &#8220;Tax Benefits&#8221;).&#160;&#160;Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code limits the ability of a company to take advantage of Tax Benefits when an ownership change occurs.&#160;&#160;In general, an &#8220;ownership change&#8221; under Section 382 occurs if there is a cumulative percentage change in the Company&#8217;s ownership by certain stockholders over a rolling three-year period.&#160;&#160;The Plan is designed to reduce the likelihood that the Company will experience an ownership change.&#160;&#160;In connection with the adoption of the Plan in 2010, the Company declared a dividend of one preferred stock purchase right (&#8220;Rights&#8221;), for each outstanding share of its common stock to holders of record on September 27, 2010.&#160;&#160;Subject to certain exceptions, the Rights generally are not exercisable until certain stockholders increase their ownership in the Company in excess of certain percentages.</font></div></div>

FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TRIAD GUARANTY INC.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">(Parent Company)</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><a id="Parent_Notes" name="Parent_Notes"><!--EFPlaceholder--></a>SUPPLEMENTARY NOTES</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">1.&#160;&#160;Basis of Presentation and Significant Accounting Policies</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In the parent company financial statements, investment in subsidiaries is stated at cost plus equity in undistributed losses of the subsidiaries.&#160;&#160;Dividends received from the subsidiaries are shown as investment income. The share of net income of subsidiaries is included in income using the equity method. The accompanying parent company financial statements should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included as part of this annual report on Form&#160;10-K.</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">2.&#160;&#160;Nature of Operations</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Triad Guaranty Inc. (&#8220;TGI&#8221;) is a holding company which, through its wholly-owned subsidiary, Triad Guaranty Insurance Corporation (&#8220;TGIC&#8221;), is a nationwide mortgage guaranty insurer pursuing a run-off of its existing in-force book of business.&#160;&#160;Mortgage insurance allows buyers to achieve homeownership with a reduced down payment, facilitates the sale of mortgage loans in the secondary market, and protects lenders from credit default-related expenses.&#160;&#160;The term &#8220;run-off&#8221; as used in these financial statements means continuing to service existing mortgage guaranty insurance policies but not writing any new policies.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Unless the context requires otherwise, references to &#8220;Triad&#8221; in this Annual Report on Form 10-K refer to the operations of TGIC and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Triad Guaranty Assurance Corporation (&#8220;TGAC&#8221;).&#160;&#160;References to the &#8220;Company&#8221; refer collectively to the operations of TGI and Triad.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TGIC is an Illinois-domiciled mortgage guaranty insurance company and TGAC is an Illinois-domiciled mortgage guaranty reinsurance company. The Illinois Department of Insurance (the &#8220;Insurance Department&#8221;) is the primary regulator of both TGIC and TGAC.&#160;&#160;The Illinois Insurance Code grants broad powers to the Insurance Department and its director (collectively, the &#8220;Department&#8221;) to enforce rules or exercise discretion over almost all significant aspects of Triad&#8217;s insurance business.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Triad ceased issuing new commitments for mortgage guaranty insurance coverage in 2008 and is operating its business in run-off under two Corrective Orders issued by the Department, as discussed in &#8220;Corrective Orders&#8221; below.&#160;&#160;The first Corrective Order was issued in 2008.&#160;&#160;The second Corrective Order was issued in 2009.&#160;&#160;Servicing existing policies during run-off includes:</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"></font><br />&#160;</div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">billing and collecting premiums on policies that remain in force;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">cancelling coverage at the insured&#8217;s request;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">working with borrowers in default to remedy the default and/or mitigate losses;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">reviewing policies for the existence of misrepresentation, fraud or non-compliance with stated programs; and</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">settling all legitimate filed claims per the provisions of the policies and the two Corrective Orders issued by the Department.</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The term &#8220;settled,&#8221; as used in these financial statements in the context of the payment of a claim, refers to the satisfaction of Triad&#8217;s obligations following the submission of valid claims by its policyholders.&#160;&#160;Prior to June 2009, valid claims were settled solely by a cash payment.&#160;&#160;As required by the second Corrective Order, effective on and after June 1, 2009, valid claims are settled by a combination of 60% in cash and 40% in the form of a deferred payment obligation (&#8220;DPO&#8221;).&#160;&#160;The Corrective Orders, among other things, allow management to continue to operate Triad under the close supervision of the Department, include restrictions on the distribution of dividends or interest on surplus notes payable to TGI by Triad, and include certain requirements on the payment of claims.&#160;&#160;Failure to comply with the provisions of the Corrective Orders could result in the imposition of fines or penalties or subject Triad to further legal proceedings, including receivership proceedings for the conservation, rehabilitation, or liquidation of Triad.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">3.&#160;&#160;Corrective Orders</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"></font>&#160;</div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Triad has entered into two Corrective Orders with the Department. Among other things, the Corrective Orders:</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require the oversight of the Department on substantially all operating matters;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Prohibit all stockholder dividends from Triad to TGI without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Prohibit interest and principal payments on Triad&#8217;s surplus note to TGI without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Restrict Triad from making any payments or entering into any transaction that involves the transfer of assets to, or liabilities from, any affiliated parties without the prior approval of the Department;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require Triad to obtain prior written approval from the Department before entering into certain transactions with unaffiliated parties;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require that all valid claims under Triad&#8217;s mortgage guaranty insurance policies are settled 60% in cash and 40% by recording a DPO;</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require the accrual of simple interest on the DPO at the same average net rate earned by Triad&#8217;s investment portfolio; and</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"><tr valign="top"><td style="WIDTH: 45pt"><div><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160; </font></div></td><td style="WIDTH: 9pt"><div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-FAMILY: Symbol, serif">&#183;</font></font></div></td><td><div align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Require that loss reserves in financial statements prepared in accordance with Statutory Accounting Principles (&#8220;SAP&#8221;) as set forth in the Illinois Insurance Code or prescribed by the Department be established to reflect the cash portion of the estimated claim settlement but not the DPO.</font></div></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The second Corrective Order provides financial thresholds, specifically regarding our statutory risk-to-capital ratio and our level of statutory policyholders&#8217; surplus that, if met, may indicate that the Department should reduce the DPO percentage and/or require distributions to DPO holders.&#160;&#160;The Corrective Orders required that the Department consider whether such changes should be made or payments allowed from time to time.&#160;&#160;In January 2012, Triad was notified by the Department that based upon Triad&#8217;s surplus position, risk-to-capital ratio and the continued economic uncertainty, the Department had determined that it was inappropriate to reduce the DPO percentage or require Triad to make a distribution to the DPO holders.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Failure to comply with the provisions of the Corrective Orders or any other violation of the Illinois Insurance Code may result in the imposition of fines or penalties or subject Triad to further legal proceedings, including the institution by the Department of receivership proceedings for the conservation, rehabilitation or liquidation of Triad.&#160;&#160;Any such actions would likely lead TGI to institute a proceeding seeking relief from creditors under U.S. bankruptcy laws, or otherwise consider dissolution of the Company.&#160;&#160;See Item 1A, &#8220;Risk Factors&#8221; for more information.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">4.&#160;&#160;Going Concern</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company prepares its financial statements presented in this annual report on Form 10-K in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (&#8220;GAAP&#8221;).&#160;&#160;The financial statements for Triad that are provided to the Department and that form the basis for our corrective plan required by the Corrective Orders were prepared in accordance with SAP as set forth in the Illinois Insurance Code or prescribed by the Department.&#160;&#160;The primary difference between GAAP and SAP for Triad at December 31, 2011 was the reporting requirements relating to the DPOs stipulated in the second Corrective Order.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A deficit in assets occurs when recorded liabilities exceed recorded assets in financial statements prepared under GAAP.&#160;&#160;A deficiency in policyholders&#8217; surplus occurs when recorded liabilities exceed recorded assets in financial statements prepared under SAP.&#160;&#160;A deficit in assets at any particular point in time under GAAP is not necessarily a measure of current insolvency or future insolvency.&#160;&#160;However, the Company believes that if Triad were to report a deficiency in policyholders&#8217; surplus under SAP for an extended period of time, Illinois law may require the Department to seek receivership of Triad, which could compel TGI to institute a proceeding seeking relief from creditors under U.S. bankruptcy laws, or otherwise consider dissolution of the Company.&#160;&#160;The second Corrective Order was designed in part to help Triad maintain its policyholders&#8217; surplus.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company has prepared its financial statements on a going concern basis under GAAP, which contemplates the realization of assets and the satisfaction of liabilities and commitments in the normal course of business.&#160;&#160;However, there is substantial doubt as to the Company's ability to continue as a going concern.&#160;&#160;This uncertainty is based on, among other things, the possible failure of Triad to comply with the provisions of the Corrective Orders and the Company's ability to generate enough income over the term of the remaining run-off to overcome its $703.6 million deficit in assets at December 31, 2011.&#160;&#160;The consolidated financial statements that are presented in this report do not include any accounting adjustments that reflect the financial risks of Triad entering receivership proceedings or otherwise not continuing as a going concern.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">5.&#160;&#160;Investments</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The cost or amortized cost and the fair value of investments, other than the investment in the subsidiaries held by TGI, and cash holdings is as follows:</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div></div><div><table style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%"><tr><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 2px" valign="bottom"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160; </font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 2px" valign="bottom"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 2px solid" valign="bottom" colspan="14"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">At December 31, 2011</font></div></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 2px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr><tr><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 2px solid" valign="bottom"><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px" valign="bottom" align="right" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">$</font></td><td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: black 4px double; TEXT-ALIGN: right" valign="bottom" width="9%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">1,060,036</font></td><td style="PADDING-BOTTOM: 4px; TEXT-ALIGN: left" valign="bottom" nowrap="nowrap" width="1%"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: times new roman">&#160;</font></td></tr></table></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The foregoing reconciliation indicates a redundancy developed during 2011 and 2010 based upon the reserve for losses and LAE recorded as of the previous year-end.&#160;&#160;<font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">During 2011, the small redundancy developed primarily as a result of actual rescission and denial activity being greater than we anticipated.&#160; </font>In 2010, the Company experienced favorable development compared to its assumptions, primarily related to rescissions and also adjusted the frequency factors utilized in the reserve methodology downward as a result of the actual experience, which generated&#160;&#160;a large redundancy in that year.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company provided reserves on reported defaults using assumptions that estimate the projected &#8220;frequency&#8221; (percentage of defaults that will ultimately be paid as claims) and &#8220;severity&#8221; (percentage of our exposure on each individual default that will ultimately be paid as a claim).&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s estimates utilized in the reserve process for frequency and severity are impacted by historical trends adjusted for changing market conditions.&#160;&#160;Actual cure and rescission rates experienced that are higher/lower than those anticipated can lead to better/worse than expected loss development and to a redundancy/deficiency in the prior loss reserves. Unanticipated changes in home prices, unemployment, economic activity, as well as social and/or cultural changes that lead to increased/decreased acceptance of mortgage defaults (even when the borrower has the ability to pay) can impact the actual frequency and severity realized compared to the levels anticipated in the reserve assumptions at the beginning of the year.&#160;&#160;A negative impact to frequency and severity can lead to adverse development, which would result in a deficiency.&#160;&#160;Changes in the frequency and severity factors are accounted for as a change in accounting estimate and are reported as an expense or benefit in the year in which external factors caused the change in assumptions.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">During 2011, the Company&#8217;s actual cure rates and rescission rates were&#160;slightly favorable compared to&#160;our expectations at the beginning of the year.&#160;&#160;However, during 2010, the Company experienced positive cure activity, partially due to HAMP and other loan modification programs.&#160; In addition, the Company experienced positive rescission activity during 2010.&#160; These positive results contributed to the redundant reserve development during 2010.&#160; The reserve factors at December 31, 2010 reflected cure and rescission activity, among other items, experienced in 2010.&#160;&#160;</font></div>

      20571000
      19575000
      <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">13.&#160;&#160;Contingencies</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company is involved in litigation and other legal proceedings in the ordinary course of business as well as the matters identified below.&#160;&#160;No reserves have been established in the financial statements regarding current litigation as the potential liability, if any, is not probable or cannot be reasonably estimated.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On February 6, 2009, James L. Phillips served a complaint alleging violations of federal securities laws against TGI and two of its officers in the United States District Court, Middle District of North Carolina on behalf of a purported class of persons who acquired the common stock of the Company between October 26, 2006 and April 1, 2008.&#160;&#160;TGI filed its motion to dismiss the amended complaint on August 21, 2009 and on January 27, 2012, the Magistrate Judge recommended that TGI&#8217;s motion to dismiss be granted.&#160;&#160;The plaintiff&#160;has indicated his intent to&#160;appeal the decision or move to amend the complaint.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On September 4, 2009, Triad filed a complaint against American Home Mortgage (&#8220;AHM&#8221;) in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware seeking rescission of multiple master mortgage guaranty insurance policies (&#8220;master policies&#8221;) and declaratory relief.&#160;&#160;The complaint seeks relief from AHM as well as all owners of loans insured under the master policies by way of a defendant class action.&#160;&#160;Triad alleged that AHM failed to follow the delegated insurance underwriting guidelines approved by Triad, that this failure breached the master policies as well as the implied covenants of good faith and fair dealing, and that these breaches were so substantial and fundamental that the intent of the master policies could not be fulfilled and Triad should be excused from its obligations under the master policies.&#160;&#160;Three groups of current owners and/or servicers of AHM-originated loans filed motions to intervene in the lawsuit, which were granted by the Court on May 10 and October 29, 2010.&#160;&#160;On March 4, 2011, Triad amended its complaint to add a count alleging fraud in the inducement.&#160;&#160;On March 25, 2011, each of the interveners filed a motion to dismiss.&#160;&#160;Triad filed its answer and answering brief in opposition to the motions to dismiss on May 27, 2011 and the interveners filed their reply briefs on July 13, 2011.&#160;&#160;The total amount of risk originated under the AHM master policies, accounting for any applicable stop-loss limits associated with Modified Pool contracts and less risk originated on policies that have been subsequently rescinded, was $1.4 billion, of which $0.7 billion remained in force at December 31, 2011.&#160;&#160;Triad continues to accept premiums and process claims under the master policies, with the earned premiums and settled losses reflected in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income (Loss).&#160;&#160;However, as a result of the litigation, Triad ceased remitting claim payments to companies servicing loans originated by AHM and the liability for losses settled but not paid is included in &#8220;Accrued expenses and other liabilities&#8221; on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.&#160;&#160;Triad has not recognized any benefit in its financial statements pending the outcome of the litigation.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On March 5, 2010, Countrywide Home Loans, Inc. filed a lawsuit in the Los Angeles County Superior Court of the State of California alleging breach of contract and seeking a declaratory judgment that bulk rescissions of flow loans is improper and that Triad is improperly rescinding loans under the terms of its master policies.&#160;&#160;On May 10, 2010 the case was designated as complex and transferred to the Court&#8217;s Complex Litigation Program.&#160;&#160;Non-binding mediation occurred on July 22, 2011 with a follow-up mediation session on October 13, 2011.&#160;&#160;The parties are in discussions to settle this matter.&#160;&#160;In the event that a settlement is not successfully concluded, Triad intends to vigorously defend this matter.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">On December 19, 2011, and January 17, 2012, complaints were served against TGIC in the United States District Court, Central District of California, and United States District Court, Eastern District of Pennsylvania, respectively. The plaintiffs purport to represent a class of persons whose loans were insured by a mortgage guaranty insurance policy and reinsured through a captive reinsurer.&#160;&#160;The complaints allege that such reinsurance is in violation of the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act.&#160;&#160;In each case, the lender, captive reinsurer, and various mortgage guaranty insurers were sued. Triad did not provide mortgage guaranty insurance on the named plaintiffs&#8217; loans in either lawsuit and has requested that plaintiffs voluntarily dismiss Triad in both lawsuits.&#160;&#160;Triad intends to vigorously defend this matter.&#160; The cases have been stayed at the request of the plaintiff pending the outcome of another case pending before the U.S. Supreme Court.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (&#8220;CFPB&#8221;) issued a letter to Triad Guaranty Inc. on January 3, 2012, advising TGI that it was investigating premium ceding practices by mortgage insurers, lenders, and their captive reinsurers and requested certain information from Triad. Triad is cooperating with the CFPB in its investigation.</font></div>
      <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">8.&#160;&#160;Employee Benefit Plans</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">All of the Company&#8217;s employees are eligible to participate in its 401(k) Profit Sharing Plan.&#160;&#160;Under the plan, employees are automatically enrolled to contribute 4% of their salary unless they elect to not participate or to participate at a different contribution level.&#160;&#160;For the year ended December 31, 2011, employees may contribute up to 25% of their annual compensation, up to a maximum of $16,500, with an additional $5,500 contribution available to those individuals who have reached the age of 50.&#160;&#160;The Company makes a matching contribution on behalf of each participating employee equal to 100% of the first 3% of the employee's deferred salary, plus 50% of the employee's deferred salary greater than 3% but not exceeding 5%.&#160;&#160;The Company&#8217;s expense associated with the plan&#160;<font style="DISPLAY: inline; BACKGROUND-COLOR: #ffffff">were approximately $0.1 million</font> for&#160;both years ended December&#160;31, 2011 and 2010.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Additionally, the Company has established and funded a Severance Trust that qualifies as an employee benefit plan under ERISA.&#160;&#160;The Severance Trust is non-contributory by the employees and its sole purpose is to provide severance payments to employees in accordance with the Company&#8217;s Severance Plan in the event that Triad is placed into bankruptcy or taken over by the Department.&#160;&#160;At December 31, 2011, the Company had placed assets with a fair value of $6.4 million in the trust.&#160;&#160;No severance expense is recognized until an employee is notified of a fixed termination date.&#160;&#160;During 2011 and 2010, severance costs amounted to $0.2 million and $1.6 million, respectively.</font></div></div>
      <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">3.&#160;&#160;Investments</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">All fixed maturity securities are classified as &#8220;available-for-sale&#8221; and are carried at fair value.&#160;&#160;Approximately 81% of the Company&#8217;s total invested assets reported at December 31, 2011 were held in a separate account pursuant to a custodial arrangement to support the DPO liability and related accrued interest as required by the second Corrective Order, compared to 49% at December 31, 2010.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;Unrealized gains on available-for-sale securities, net of tax, are reported as a separate component of accumulated other comprehensive income in shareholders&#8217; equity.&#160;&#160;Due to the Company operating in run-off under the supervision by the Department and the uncertainty surrounding the Company&#8217;s ability to continue as a going concern, the Company is no longer in a position to retain a security that is in an unrealized loss position, even on a temporary basis, until it potentially recovers value.&#160;&#160;Accordingly, the Company recognizes an other than temporary impairment loss on all securities for which the fair value is less than the amortized cost at the balance sheet date.&#160;&#160;Impairment losses are recognized as realized investment losses in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income (Loss).&#160;&#160;If the Company believes that the recorded impairment was due to reasons other than credit related, the difference between the impaired value and principal amount will be amortized as a component of interest income through the anticipated maturity date.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The cost or amortized cost, gross unrealized gains and losses, and the fair value of investments at December&#160;31, 2011 and 2010 are as follows:</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Unrealized gains do not necessarily represent future gains that the Company will realize.&#160;&#160;The value of the Company&#8217;s investment portfolio will vary depending on overall market interest rates, credit spreads, and changing conditions related to specific securities, as well as other factors. Volatility may increase in periods of uncertain market or economic conditions.&#160;&#160;Unrealized gains at both December 31, 2011 and 2010 were due primarily to a decline in interest rates from those at the time of initial purchase, although the recovery in value of previously impaired fixed maturity securities also contributes to the level of unrealized gains.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Gross realized gains in 2011 were primarily due to discretionary sales to realize investment gains given the low market yield environment. Gross realized gains in 2010 were primarily due to the discretionary sales of corporate securities to reposition the average maturity of the investment portfolio.&#160;&#160;Gross realized losses in 2011 and 2010 were primarily attributable to the write downs of other-than-temporarily impaired securities with market values less than the respective book value as of the balance sheet date.&#160;&#160;Approximately 18% of the write-downs during 2011 were related to securities that are credit concerns, compared to 7% in 2010.&#160;&#160;Because the value of the existing investments is in part dependent on the difference between the coupon rate compared to the current market rates for similar securities, an increase in market interest rates most likely would bring about further realized losses.</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block;       <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">12.&#160;&#160;Long-term Debt</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In July 2010, TGI repurchased and retired the entire $35.0 million par value of its Notes for an aggregate purchase price of $4.9 million.       <div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">5.&#160;&#160;Commitments</font></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt"><br /></div><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 0pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt"><div style="DISPLAY: block; MARGIN-LEFT: 0pt; TEXT-INDENT: 18pt; MARGIN-RIGHT: 0pt" align="left"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company leases its office facilities and equipment under operating leases. Net rental expense for all leases was $0.3 million for 2011 and $0.4 million for 2010.&#160;&#160;&#160;Net rental expense for both years accounts for amounts collected from other tenants which the Company sublets.&#160;&#160;Future minimum payments under non-cancellable operating leases, excluding amounts from tenants that sublet from the Company, at December 31, 2011 are as follows:</font></div></div><div style="DISPLAY: block;                Deferred Payment Obligation
          Unsecured obligation to policyholders for claims settled, including interest accrued, under corrective order issued by the Illinois Department of Insurance. Claims were settled 60% with cash and 40% by the issuance of a deferred payment obligation.
          Deferred payment obligation including accrued interest

          The net change during the reporting period of the Deferred Payment Obligation, including interest accrued, for claims settled 60% in cash and 40% by the issue of the Deferred Payment obligation.

               Reserve for Losses and LAE [Abstract]
               Liability Reserve Estimate [Text Block]
          Disclosure for estimating the liability of the reporting entity as of the balance sheet date for the ultimate cost of settling reported and unreported claims incurred and claims adjustment expenses (including effects of inflation and other societal and economic factors).
          Reserve for Losses and LAE
               Going Concern [Abstract]
               Going Concern [Text Block]
          The entire disclosure of accounting policy for reporting when there is a substantial doubt about an entity's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time (generally a year from the balance sheet date).
          Going Concern

   v2.4.0.6
                           Investments
         
         12 Months Ended
       
                           Dec. 31, 2011
         
       
                Investments [Abstract]
          
       
                Investments
         3.  Investments
All fixed maturity securities are classified as “available-for-sale” and are carried at fair value.  Approximately 81% of the Company’s total invested assets reported at December 31, 2011 were held in a separate account pursuant to a custodial arrangement to support the DPO liability and related accrued interest as required by the second Corrective Order, compared to 49% at December 31, 2010.
 Unrealized gains on available-for-sale securities, net of tax, are reported as a separate component of accumulated other comprehensive income in shareholders’ equity.  Due to the Company operating in run-off under the supervision by the Department and the uncertainty surrounding the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, the Company is no longer in a position to retain a security that is in an unrealized loss position, even on a temporary basis, until it potentially recovers value.  Accordingly, the Company recognizes an other than temporary impairment loss on all securities for which the fair value is less than the amortized cost at the balance sheet date.  Impairment losses are recognized as realized investment losses in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income (Loss).  If the Company believes that the recorded impairment was due to reasons other than credit related, the difference between the impaired value and principal amount will be amortized as a component of interest income through the anticipated maturity date.
The cost or amortized cost, gross unrealized gains and losses, and the fair value of investments at December 31, 2011 and 2010 are as follows:

Unrealized gains do not necessarily represent future gains that the Company will realize.  The value of the Company’s investment portfolio will vary depending on overall market interest rates, credit spreads, and changing conditions related to specific securities, as well as other factors. Volatility may increase in periods of uncertain market or economic conditions.  Unrealized gains at both December 31, 2011 and 2010 were due primarily to a decline in interest rates from those at the time of initial purchase, although the recovery in value of previously impaired fixed maturity securities also contributes to the level of unrealized gains.
Securities with a fair value of $5.9 million and $6.4 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, are held in trust related to specific severance and retention plans and are included in Other Assets on the Company’s Consolidated Balance Sheets.  Unrealized gains on these securities were $0.5 million and $0.4 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
The amortized cost and estimated fair value of investments in fixed maturity securities, at December 31, 2011, are summarized by stated maturity below.  Asset-backed, commercial mortgage-backed, and residential mortgage-backed securities are presented separately below because they generally provide for periodic payments of principal.

Gross realized gains in 2011 were primarily due to discretionary sales to realize investment gains given the low market yield environment. Gross realized gains in 2010 were primarily due to the discretionary sales of corporate securities to reposition the average maturity of the investment portfolio.  Gross realized losses in 2011 and 2010 were primarily attributable to the write downs of other-than-temporarily impaired securities with market values less than the respective book value as of the balance sheet date.  Approximately 18% of the write-downs during 2011 were related to securities that are credit concerns, compared to 7% in 2010.  Because the value of the existing investments is in part dependent on the difference between the coupon rate compared to the current market rates for similar securities, an increase in market interest rates most likely would bring about further realized losses.

At December 31, 2011 and 2010, investments with an amortized cost of $8.2 million and $8.8 million
, respectively, were on deposit with various state insurance departments to satisfy regulatory requirements.  At December 31, 2011 and 2010, assets with a market value of $629.7 million and $415.7 million, respectively, were supporting the Company’s DPO obligations pursuant to the second Corrective Order.

                           X
         
                                 - Definition
                 Tabular disclosure of investments in certain debt and equity securities (and certain other trading assets) which include all debt and equity securities (other than those equity securities accounted for under the equity or cost methods of accounting) with readily determinable fair values. Other trading assets include assets that are carried on the balance sheet at fair value and held for trading purposes.  A debt security represents a creditor relationship with an enterprise that is in the form of a security. Debt securities include, among other items, US Treasury securities, US government securities, municipal securities, corporate bonds, convertible debt, commercial paper, and all securitized debt instruments. An equity security represents an ownership interest in an enterprise or the right to acquire or dispose of an ownership interest in an enterprise at fixed or determinable prices. Equity securities include, among other things, common stock, certain preferred stock, warrant rights, call options, and put options, but do not include convertible debt. An entity may opt to provide the reader with additional narrative text to better understand the nature of investments in debt and equity securities (and other trading assets).
